displayed_text: Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then I’ll print out these consent forms for you that you can take and sort of that he can look at as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we can sort of decide which one makes more sense for you, or none of them may make any sense, and that really because your scans or worse, you’re having more symptoms. You know the textbook answer right now is go to chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm. Patient: And how soon would that start? Doctor: Uh that would be more—again, based on scans and scheduling. Patient: Okay and then who’s going to order the scans? Doctor: So that’s what I’ve got to talk to Dr. G__ about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you’ve already got the test scans, what’s the plan? Because we need to get pictures to sort of say yes, you’ve progressed. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And it hardly ever goes to you know oh look it’s all gone. Maybe you get one or two things Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and you just don’t see it, but your lymph nodes are substantially smaller. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Substantially, so this sucker’s totally working because you know the drop of your PSA not including today, but in the past have all been down. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So I’m fine with it. We fuss over big joints, hips, legs… Patient: Okay. Doctor: Shoulders because they can crack. Family Member: We were thinking it was right and not left.

Family Member: It’s just what bothers me about it is the pain that sometimes he go through. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Sometimes the pain can be a ten and then sometimes the pain can be a four. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If he had a four, I’d be comfortable with him being on the bike – Doctor: Yeah, I know. Family Member: - but when he have a ten… Doctor: Well and the hard part is it’s right here, it’s this pelvic pain that Dr. P___ is dealing with. Patient: No, no it wasn’t. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It was this thing over here, whatever. Doctor: And that, I mean it’s all kind of, but it’s all here, it’s not here,

Family Member: Not for now. Okay. That’s good news. Doctor: You know, but someday maybe. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, it is an effective thing we use, but I think we have other things to try before. Family Member: Awesome. (sighs) Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down.

Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: Or if you want to eat iron-rich foods, uh, like- Family Member: But you’re thinking this is basically because of the medication? The study medication? Doctor: Yeah. I’m pretty sure. I’m pretty sure because, I mean, he actually had some degree of mild anemia before he went on the study. Part of that could have been from the cancer of the bone or marrow, specifically, but clearly when he went on the drug, it got worse, and it dropped back one to two points. So, uh, but you might need a transfusion, however. But that’s a possibility. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: So as of today, you know, stopping the . Okay? Uh, let’s plan to do, uh, forgot what the lab was. Is it K___? Family Member: It’s K___ lab. L___ will, uh, communicate with A___ from K___, and she’ll, uh, we’ll send her the script. Doctor: Please let L___ know about this. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we’ll get you a prescription through K___ to do a blood test next Tuesday, let’s say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or whatever day works for you. And, and that’s one of the precautions to see if, if the stopping of the drug for a week is causing the hemoglobin to increase on its own. And if it’s not, and we need some help with that, that’s when a blood transfusion would come into play.

Patient: When do you, when do you wanna start the trial? Doctor: You already got your scan. We start the biopsy. We go. No, no time wasted. Patient: Well I got – I got to do the biopsy? Doctor: Yes! Patient: What the hell, doc? Doctor: Don’t look at me! It’s science! You’re contributing! Patient: You gonna put me to sleep or what? Doctor: Oh, yeah. Yeah. You’ll be fine. Patient: Oh, man! No!!! Doc! C’mon! Doctor: You’ll be fine! Family Member: Seriously? Patient: How you goin’, do whatcha, you goin’ up my ass? What are you doin’?

Patient: Yeah. Patient: Huh. Yeah bring in, lets take a look at it… Doctor: Yeah you’ll probably need the copy of the labs anyway. Patient: Yeah but that’s what… Doctor: You’ll have to take it to B____ too. Patient: Huh? Doctor: I want you to take the blood work, the tests that I give you to B____ also. Patient: Okay. Oh, okay. Doctor: That way they have a copy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay, okay. Yeah because that’s what we did last…

Family Member: So he had Patient: For eight years. Family Member: Weird sleep rhythms then. And then he, he did, um, move into a period of time where he worked a more normal, more universal schedule. Yeah and then started this, you know, this investigation thing which is very, sometimes it’s very haphazard. Doctor: Okay. Well, last time you were talking about kidney stone pain and that you felt like you were peeing razor blades. Patient: Yes, none. That had happened, maybe two more pees. (Laughs) Doctor: And, have you been to the hospital? Patient: Mmm, no. Family Member: No. Not since -- Patient: Not since the, the kidney stone prior to the last one. Doctor: Appetite okay? Patient: Oh. Yeah. Comfort, comfort eating has been my, my, uh, default since I was a kid. So. Doctor: Okay, bowels are - weight, uh, any changes?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’d have to make sure there’s, you know, nothing really going on but sometimes people feel a little bit off kilter. Patient: Vertigo, or-? Doctor: Uh, no. It’s almost just like, you know, you stand up and you’re ooh. Not like it’s spinning, but you just don’t have a sense of where you are, and then you right yourself, but, obviously, we don’t want you to fall. Um, so if you start to feel like, you know, there’s some unsteadiness, we need to know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a lot of paperwork if you fall. Family Member: Oh, that’s at home. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s still a lot of paperwork if you fall. Just don’t call the clinic. Less paperwork. Yeah. Because then I have to deal with it, and so, yeah, let’s not follow through. Family Member: Less paperwork. Patient: Um. Doctor: Good questions. Man. Patient: Also, some neurologist thing, you know, but, syncope.

Patient: R____. Family Member: R____. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Preferably B______ in uh W____ even. Doctor: So there’s a large nephrology practice at B______. And they’re scattered everywhere. Patient: Right. Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Um but you know this is one guy who I really know him well ‘cause he took care of my dad so his group is very good and there’s like a gazillion of them, but they’re all good. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But you actually need I think at this stage of the game from an honest to goodness nephrologist to really manage this part. Patient: I had one several years ago. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Then I got a, then I got Doctor: Then, you got to try it. I don’t see you using it. Patient: I got it down ‘cuz it don’t, it don’t really be working for me. You know what I’m sayin’? ‘Cuz all I do is when I stop, I lean on it, lean down on it. I’d settle for the one with the seat on it. Now see, that’s the one that, um, I gotta see, if, if you can, can you see when the next time I can get one? The one with the seat on it? Doctor: The walker with the seat? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’ll give you script for that to take… Patient: Now see, I have, I have to, I have to always sit, I have to always sit down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know, because I be fatigued. Doctor: I see. Not a problem. Patient: You know what I’m saying? And, that, that’s the only problem (XXX) Doctor: I’ll give you a script take it over to Vincent’s or whatever and see what they say.

Patient: No. Well, they were having a problem getting my- Doctor: Yes. Exactly. Well, the problem is, it’s just this bad cycle you’re in. You know? Then you’re tired. It comes around and around. Family Member: Yeah just make better choices. Doctor: Okay. Glad we had this conversation about your diabetes in a prostate cancer clinic, but that’s actually number one. Doctor: Plus, you know, you’re getting that stupid, you know, Lupron shot from us, or, all the time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Are we the ones that give it to you? Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. K___ gives it. Doctor: Yeah. From us. I’m like why did I think it wasn’t us? Oh, it’s us. And you know we make your diabetes like even worse. So I feel partly responsible. I’m just trying to make sure you stay healthy. No carbs. Patient: Okay. Then, we’re going to see you, see you in six weeks? Doctor: That’s it. Enjoy yourself.

Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know. Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something.

Family Member: No. He did not. Hum. Doctor: Okay. So did you explain anything to her? Patient: No. She tell me- Family Member: No. But, yes, this is why, right. Yes. This is why I’m here. Doctor: Ah. Okay. Family Member: Because I can’t get a good understanding. Doctor: Okay. Okay. We know the baseline stuff – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - that he has. Family Member: Exactly. Doctor: That’s basically still there. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But because the PSA was doing a little bit of this creep up-

Patient: Clinical study? Doctor: Yeah it’s a clinical trial a hormonal agent that has at least three clinically shown promising results. Patient: And that would be here? Doctor: Then it would have to be. Family Member: So that’s different… Doctor: That’s one option. Family Member: …than chemo, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Does any others have xxx]? Doctor: I think and since his cancer has shown us over the years that it was very sensitive to hormonal therapies, I would advocate doing that – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - unless I see you know big huge lymph nodes or some xxx] in there that I’m majorly concerned about. Okay?
